Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Documenting the Oral Tradition of Northern Paiute, a Uto-Aztecan language

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The linguistic diversity of North America is well-established in terms of the numerous language families represented on this continent. However, the vitality of these languages is threatened, making the documentation and maintenance of surviving Native languages all the more pressing. The Native American Languages Act, passed by the U.S. Congress in 1990, enacted into policy the recognition of the unique status and importance of Native American languages. The opportunity to document the speech used in oral traditions and the verbal arts for Native American languages is urgent, especially when this occurs in communities where the language retains considerable vitality and is still used extensively by speakers. This project will document oral traditions, and cultural and ethnohistorical knowledge where the indigenous language usage and speakers' traditional knowledge are very strong. The documentation will form the core material analyzed in a doctoral dissertation produced by the CoPI. Broader impacts include a publicly available deposit of the recordings and transcriptions at the California Language Archive at the University of California, Berkeley, and the uses of this material by the tribe to support language revitalization and educational activities in culture, history and related areas.

The Fort McDermitt Paiute-Shoshone Reservation is an isolated Native community situated across the Nevada-Oregon border, formed when the Atsakɨda kwa Nɨmɨ (the people of the Red Mountain), were joined by families from neighboring areas looking for a Paiute safe haven as Euro-American settlers expanded settlements westward. Northern Paiute, a member of the Uto-Aztecan language family, is used extensively in this community by about three hundred speakers. This project will record the Northern Paiute language in both casual and formal speech. It will also document Paiute perspectives on past events as well as more distant collective history for the community, examining how oral traditions are used, and performed, as well as how they contrast with the Euro-American historical discourse. Native American languages differ in their linguistic and information structure from Indo-European languages like English. As a result, documenting Native American cultures requires serious attention to not only the structure of these languages, but also to the performance of verbal arts and how grammatical structures interact to express historical and other knowledge. The CoPI, a doctoral student at Indiana University, will analyze the documentation to explore how oral traditions in Northern Paiute are performed. The analysis will include how meaning is expressed in both the physical body in performance and via the grammar through instrumental prefixes, morphemes referring to gestures or parts of the body. Elicitation strategies range from videorecording of an annual storytelling festival (started in 2016), the use of focus groups in which people come together and discuss specific topics of the history of the community, and interviews and field trips to places of relevance to the community's collective history. By transcribing, analyzing, and translating Northern Paiute texts, the project will expand the linguistic, cultural, and historic record for the community and for researchers in history, anthropology, and folklore, as well as other allied disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant facilitated ethnographic, ethnohistoric, and ethnolinguistic research on oral traditions of the Fort McDermitt Paiute-Shoshone Indian Tribe. The co-PI, Thierry Veyrié, conducted sixteen months of ethnographic fieldwork working with fluent Paiute elders of the community and aided in the transmission of the community’s heritage by assisting in producing new materials and through collaborative work on older ones, such as recordings made by Professor Sven Liljeblad in the 1960’s.

From the point of view of the ethnohistoric documentation of the northwestern Great Basin, the data produced by this project sheds new light on the Paiute, Bannock, and Shoshone sociopolitical dynamics before the 1860’s and the colonization of the area. It also provides new accounts to examine the multicultural history of Nevada and the Frontier, and the different perspectives it entails. Given the scarce published documentary record on the history of Native and European American relations in the area, the project makes important contributions to regional and national history.

The recordings from this project also contribute to the study of performance of native oral traditions and embodied culture. Several video recordings of Paiute storytelling were produced, and video recordings made in the 1990’s were translated. The new recordings and the translation of existing ones may provide new insights in gestural features in native expression.

From the point of view of the linguistic research on the Northern Paiute language, this project also provided new data on what is commonly called Instrumental Prefixes, and their allowable and non-allowable combinations.

Beyond the research merits of the project, the collaborative work that it involved has served the purpose of sensitizing the community about language maintenance and may result in new projects pertaining to language work and transmission. All recordings and products can be used for educational purposes. Videos can support language learning and cultural awareness, and handouts or lessons can be created from these and other materials.

The project co-PI produced new recordings of the endangered Northern Paiute language from the community of McDermitt (Nevada-Oregon), supported the expression of native oral history in Paiute and in English to diversify the historic documentary record, and collaborated in linguistic consultancy with fluent speakers of Northern Paiute to translate previously recorded but so far untranslated tapes.

The products of this grant include:

-          Over two hours of new Paiute narrative recordings that have been translated, typed, and are being processed in ELAN and FieldWorks, the first to produce time stamped transcriptions and translations, and the second to analyze the texts and produce a Paiute lexicon;

-          One 50-page collaboratively-produced booklet including thematic word and sentence lists in Northern Paiute, and hours of recorded elicitations of said booklet;

-          Several videos of elders speaking Northern Paiute;

-          Hundreds of pages of field interlinear transcription, translation, and notes.
